system_overview: An interactive visualization of Lessig's four regulatory modalities (Law, Norms, Market, Architecture/Code), using the cigarette pack as case study in 'freedom theatre.'

mindsets_paradigms.current: Law is the only form of regulation
mindsets_paradigms.target: Architecture/code is equally powerful regulatory force

organizing_principles.target: Four-force framework as integrated analysis tool

information_flows.current: Second-order effects (how code constrains future code) invisible
information_flows.intervention: User moves forces around, sees cascading effects

system_infrastructure.intervention: Single-file HTML for any regulatory domain

dynamic_processes.embedded_values: Policy analysis privileges legal expertise; code/architecture often neglected
dynamic_processes.process_redesign_opportunity: Integrated four-force analysis as standard practice

social_positionalities.power_dynamics: Legal/policy analysts hold authority; technologists seen as implementers
social_positionalities.safety_concerns: Calling out code-as-regulation can threaten tech industry narratives
social_positionalities.legitimized_expertise: Tool legitimizes systems thinking across domains

invisible_work.articulation_labor: Translating Lessig's theory into interactive form
invisible_work.emotional_labor: Navigating 'freedom' discourse that obscures actual constraints
invisible_work.unrecognized_labor: Mapping modality interactions for specific domains

embedded_systems.standards: Platform policies, API terms of service

integrated_intervention_strategies.intervention: Create interactive Lessig four modalities tool
integrated_intervention_strategies.infrastructure_work: Make code-as-regulation viscerally tangible; use cigarette pack as concrete case
Test framework on emerging regulatory domain; document modality interactions
Pull actual tax rates, platform policies, legal restrictions; show numerical force strengths

invisible_trail: Cigarette pack case study from class discussion

meta_rule: Analyze regulatory systems by asking: Which modality (Law/Norms/Market/Code) has highest leverage for change, AND what infrastructural conditions (expertise legitimization, economic incentives, platform policies) constrain which modalities can be redesigned?
